University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. Research Lecture: Astrobiology and the detection of life in our solar system https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/interdisciplinary-science/public-events/research-lectures/zita-martins/research-lecture-astrobiology-and-the-detection-of-life-in-our-solar-system Astrobiology and the detection of life in our solar system

The origin of life on Earth is one of the biggest scientific questions waiting to be answered, with the most recent theories suggesting the presence of water and a continuous supply of prebiotic organic compounds as a requirement.

The first experimental analysis on the abiotic formation of the building blocks of life was performed in 1953 by Stanley Miller, who synthesised organic compounds using a spark discharge in a mixture of reduced gases. Although this was a ground breaking result, it was later showed that the atmospheric conditions used in this experiment did not correspond to the ones of our primitive planet.

As the Earth was heavily bombarded by comets, asteroids, meteorites and interplanetary dust particle (IDPs) 4.6 to 3.8 million years ago, the exogenous delivery of organic compounds is an alternative. In fact, carbonaceous meteorites have a rich organic inventory, and may have provided the first building blocks of life to the primitive Earth. As future space missions will investigate the possibility of past and/or present extra-terrestrial life, it is important to determine how life may have originated in other places of our solar system, and how to detect possible bio-signatures.

This talk will discuss how the study of meteorites, asteroids, comets and Mars soil analogues is used to investigate the origin of life on Earth and how to detect any possible signatures of extra-terrestrial life in our solar system.

Flyer for this event

\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Zita Martins

Dr Zita Martins is a Royal Society University\ufffd\ufffdResearch Fellow at Imperial College London. Her research interests include the detection of bio-signatures in space missions, and the possible contribution of meteorites and comets to the origin of life on Earth. Dr Zita Martins has an MSc in Chemistry from Instituto Superior T\ufffd\ufffdcnico (Portugal, 2003) and a PhD in Astrobiology from the University of Leiden (The Netherlands, 2007). She was an Invited Scientist at NASA Goddard in 2005 and 2006, and an Invited Professor at the University of Nice-Sophia Antipolis (France) in 2012. After her PhD, Dr Martins moved to Imperial College London as Post-Doc Research Associate, and since 2009 she has been a Royal Society University Research Fellow.

Dr Martins is a Co-Investigator in one European Space Agency (ESA-ELIPS) space mission experiment (OREOCube) which will be on-board the International Space Station, a member of two ESA Topical Teams (Future Astrobiology Experiments in Earth orbit and beyond, and Lunar Exploitation of local planetary materials), and a Committee member of the Astrobiology Society of Britain (ASB). She has been an invited speaker in several international conferences including the Gordon Research Conference and the COSPAR Conference. Dr Martins has an active involvement with public outreach activities, including several international media interviews, and public talks at museums and Science festivals. She was selected as one of the BBC's Expert Women, and she had the honour of having her portrait sketched for the Royal Society exhibit about great women in science.

]]> No publisher lr158 Biology Natural Sciences Biological Sciences Event Astronomy Astrophysics Biochemistry Event:Lecture Interdisciplinary science 2014-11-20T17:00:00Z Event Scientists solve decades old space mystery https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/scientists-solve-decades-old-space-mystery New theory advanced for how collapsed stars become polluted \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd pointing to ominous fate that awaits planet Earth
Artist\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds impression of a massive asteroid belt in orbit around a star. The new work with SDSS data shows that similar rubble around many white dwarfs contaminates these stars with rocky material and water. Image credit: NASA-JPL / Caltech / T. Pyle (SSC)
A decades old space mystery has been solved by an international team of astronomers led by Professor Martin Barstow of our Department of Physics and Astronomy and President-elect of the Royal Astronomical Society.

Scientists investigated hot, young, white dwarfs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the super-dense remains of Sun-like stars that ran out of fuel and collapsed to about the size of the Earth. Their research is featured in MNRAS- the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, published by Oxford University Press.

It has been known that many hot white dwarfs atmospheres, essentially of pure hydrogen or pure helium, are contaminated by other elements \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd like carbon, silicon and iron.

Professor Barstow said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe new work indicates that at around a one-third of all hot white dwarfs are contaminated in this way, with the debris most likely in the form of rocky minor planet analogues. This implies that a similar proportion of stars like our Sun, as well as stars that are a little more massive like Vega and Fomalhaut, build systems containing terrestrial planets.\ufffd\ufffd This work is a form of celestial archaeology where we are studying the 'ruins' of rocky planets and/or their building blocks, following the demise of the main star."

\ufffd\ufffd

The study also points to the ultimate fate of the Earth billions of years from now- ending up as a contamination within the white dwarf Sun.

  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Space Astronomy 2014-03-26T10:31:01Z Blog Entry Catapult announces three new Centres of Excellence https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/catapult-announces-three-new-centres-of-excellence University of Leicester, University of Nottingham and British Geological Survey in new consortium The Satellite Applications Catapult, an independent technology and innovation company, has announced the launch of three new regional \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCentres of Excellence\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in satellite applications. Each new Centre will act as a focal point for Catapult activity in its local area, consolidating the links between the science knowledge base and the business community.

Business Durham, University of Strathclyde and a consortium comprising University of Leicester, University of Nottingham and British Geological Survey, were each chosen to host a new Centre by a select team comprising of Catapult and external advisors representing business and academia, after an open selection process which attracted more than a dozen proposals.

The University of Leicester is a recognised Centre of Excellence for developing new ways of using satellite data for everyday use in areas such as transport, energy & agriculture. As part of the new work with the Satellite Applications Catapult and University of Nottingham and BGS, the team will work with businesses and public bodies across the greater East Midlands to develop new ways to exploit satellite data.

Professor Paul Monks (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdfrom the Department of Chemistry said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe have been working with businesses for a number of years to enhance competitiveness, jobs and growth by using academic knowledge of space to accelerate business. This new partnership with the flagship innovation centres (Catapults) will put greater impetus behind this and allow us to work with more businesses together with our innovation partners.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Each Centre will commence activities from April 2014 with an agreed plan of actions, activities and events. Once the model is established and the value demonstrated, the Catapult plans to extend its network to include further Centres into other regions.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Astronomy Chemistry Magazine:Business Magazine:Staff 2014-03-19T12:03:15Z Blog Entry Innovative handheld mineral analyser \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthe first of its kind\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/january/innovative-handheld-mineral-analyser-2013-2018the-first-of-its-kind2019 Dr Graeme Hansford to develop inventive new device in collaboration with Bruker Elemental Dr Graeme Hansford (pictured) from the University's Space Research Centre (SRC) has recently started a collaborative project with Bruker Elemental to develop a handheld mineral analyser for mining applications \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the first of its kind.

The analyser will allow rapid mineral identification and quantification in the field through a combination of X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and will be capable of analysing mining samples for mineral content within 1 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 2 minutes.

The analyser is unique due to the insensitivity of the technique to the shape of the sample, which enables the direct analysis of samples without any form of preparation \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd something currently inconceivable using conventional XRD equipment.

Dr Hansford originally conceived of the XRD technique in early 2010, when trying to work out how to apply XRD for space applications - for example on the surface of Mars or an asteroid - without the need for any sample preparation.

This project is supported with an award from the Science and Technology Facilities Council\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Innovations Partnerships Scheme.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Business Magazine:Research Space Research Centre Astrophysics Astronomy Magazine:Student Geology Magazine:Staff 2014-01-14T12:05:00Z Blog Entry New insights into cosmic phenomena https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/december/new-insights-into-cosmic-phenomena Swift satellite catches a hundred thousand new cosmic X-ray sources An international\ufffd\ufffdAstronomy team\ufffd\ufffdat the\ufffd\ufffdUniversity has published a major list of celestial X-ray sources in the Astrophysical Journal.

The result of many years work, this list of over 150,000 high-energy stars and galaxies will be a vital resource for future astronomical studies.

Using the X-ray telescope on board the US/UK/Italian Swift satellite, the team analysed eight years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd worth of data to make the first Swift X-ray Point Source catalogue.

The X-ray camera used in this work was built at the University following a 50-year tradition of providing sensitive equipment for launch into space.\ufffd\ufffdThe University supports the efficient operation of the camera in flight, and runs a scientific data centre providing Swift results to the world within minutes of the observation.

The NASA Swift satellite was launched in November 2004 to study gamma-ray bursts: hugely powerful stellar explosions which can be seen back to the time when the Universe was only a few percent of its current age.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Physics Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Astrophysics Astronomy 2013-12-16T11:10:00Z Blog Entry Scientists using space technologies to save lives on Earth https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/december/scientists-using-space-technologies-to-save-lives-on-earth University academics \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthinking like astronauts\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Space researchers from the University are applying cutting-edge space technology to real-life applications in order to save lives on Earth.

Canada\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first astronaut, Colonel Chris Hadfield, is encouraging us all to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthink like an astronaut\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in his new memoirs, An Astronaut\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Guide to Life on Earth, and two academics from the Space Research Centre, Dr John Lees and Dr Roland Leigh, are doing just that with their innovative applications of space technology.

The researchers will be sharing their Earth applications of space technology with Colonel Hadfield who will be visiting the University and the National Space Centre on Friday 13 December as part of an international book tour.

During his visit to the University, Chris will also meet a number of Physics and Astronomy students who will share their research with him through displays and demonstrations. He will then take part in a Q&A session at the National Space Centre with school and college students from around Leicestershire.

  • Press Release

Listen to podcasts with Dr John Lees about using space technology to treat cancer and Dr Roland Leigh\ufffd\ufffddiscussing using\ufffd\ufffdspace technology to monitor pollution below:

]]> No publisher ap507 Solar System Space Astrophysics Astronomy Space Research Centre Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Physics 2013-12-11T13:40:00Z Blog Entry A New View of the Hot and Energetic Universe https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/a-new-view-of-the-hot-and-energetic-universe ESA selects the science theme for its next large mission The University is collaborating with partners including the Science Programme Committee of the European Space Agency (ESA) for its next Large (L-class) mission.

The theme is "The Hot and Energetic Universe", and the mission, using an Advanced Telescope for High ENergy Astrophysics (ATHENA),\ufffd\ufffdis expected to be launched in 2028, with the power to address some of the most fundamental questions in modern astrophysics.\ufffd\ufffd

With the new mission, astronomers will measure the properties of galaxy clusters in the distant Universe, and map the physical characteristics of the largest structures known.

This\ufffd\ufffdwill dramatically advance\ufffd\ufffdour understanding of how these structures first assembled when the Universe was just two billion years old.

Plans for a mission like\ufffd\ufffdATHENA started in an international research meeting held at the University in July 1996, entitled "The Next Generation of X-ray Observatories". Since then Leicester astronomers and instrumentation scientists have been core members of an international effort working towards the ambitious goal of understanding the universe.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Student Astronomy Astrophysics Physics 2013-11-28T16:04:19Z Blog Entry Colonel Chris Hadfield teaches students 'how to think like an astronaut' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/an-astronaut-s-guide-to-life-on-earth Former NASA astronaut and social media star to talk at University on Friday 13 December Canada\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first astronaut to walk in space, Colonel Chris\ufffd\ufffdHadfield -\ufffd\ufffdwho became an overnight sensation with his stunning space photography and educational \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhow to\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd videos -\ufffd\ufffdwill be visiting the Space Research Centre (SRC) and the National Space Centre on Friday 13 December.

During his visit to the University, Chris will meet a number of students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy who will share their research with him through displays and demonstrations. He will then take part in a Q&A session at the National Space Centre with school and college students from around Leicestershire.

His visit is\ufffd\ufffdpart of an international book tour for his memoirs, An Astronaut\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Guide to Life on Earth. The new publication provides an insight into the wisdom he has learnt from spending \ufffd\ufffd\ufffda lifetime making the impossible a reality\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and teaches us all \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhow to think like an astronaut\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

Chris first flew in space on the Russian Space station MIR and then, in April 2001, made his first visit to the International Space Station (ISS) to install its \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdrobot arm\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, CanadaArm2. More recently, Chris was flight engineer on ISS expedition 34 and the first Canadian Commander of the ISS on expedition 35 from December 2012 to May 2013. It was during his time on the ISS that Chris captivated the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds social media by tweeting his breathtaking photographs of the Earth from space.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Astronomy Astrophysics Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Magazine:Business Magazine:Student 2013-11-12T11:05:00Z Blog Entry 'Realistic' Mars landscape in Chile used for rover testing https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/october/realistic-landscape-in-chile-used-for-space-research Dr Derek Pullan and SAFER conduct Mars rover testing in Atacama Desert Dr Derek Pullan from the Space Research Centre, Department of Physics and Astronomy, is currently involved in an ESA-funded project called SAFER (Sample Field Acquisition Experiment with a Rover). The project recently took him to the Atacama desert of Northern Chile, where a prototype Mars rover equipped with sophisticated instruments was used to simulate a mission to the red planet.

Dr Pullan provided scientific input to the project, initially to help select a suitable site that had maximum geological realism for the trial and also to provide in-field expertise during the trial itself. Importantly, suitable sites for these type of tests must \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlook like Mars\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, be large-scale, uncontrolled, exhibit natural geological features, be free of vegetation, show no signs of human activity (including footprints!) and have stable weather (no chance of rain). Candidate sites in Chile, Morocco, Tenerife and the USA were originally evaluated but the team settled on Chile thanks to all the above criteria being met plus the added bonus of local support offered by ESO at the Paranal observatory close to the test site.

The SAFER project is led by the technological partners RAL Space (project lead), EADS Astrium (rover platform) and SCISYS (mission operations software), and is a follow-on to a project called SEEKER, which developed robust long range navigation software for the next generation of Mars rovers. With the inclusion of science (University of Leicester), a payload of instruments (UK, France and Switzerland) and remotely operated via a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMission Control\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in the UK, SAFER provides a more realistic framework in which to learn how to prepare for real missions to Mars.

To keep track of developments relating to SAFER, visit the project blog and the ESA portal.

To see more images, visit Dr Pullan's website.

]]> No publisher ap507 Astronomy Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student 2013-10-21T15:10:00Z Blog Entry Celebrating seven milestones in University's history https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/celebrating-seven-milestones-in-university-s-history Legacy of Leicester campaign highlights world-class University achievements The University\ufffd\ufffdis\ufffd\ufffdto celebrate seven milestones in its academic history -\ufffd\ufffdone for each of the decades since University College Leicester received the Royal Charter to become a University\ufffd\ufffd-\ufffd\ufffdat the start of the new academic year.

The Legacy of Leicester is a campaign that highlights the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds world-class achievements and reflects the breadth of its groundbreaking research.

2014 will mark the final year in his term as Vice-Chancellor for Professor Sir Robert Burgess and the year will also mark the 100th anniversary of the Great War, the University of Leicester being Britain\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds only living memorial to the First World War.

You can learn about the\ufffd\ufffdseven milestones on\ufffd\ufffdthe\ufffd\ufffddedicated University website via the links below through podcasts, talks, exhibitions and local and national publicity,:

  1. 1955 - The Making of the English Landscape Published
  2. 1966 - Mass Communication Research enters mainstream academia
  3. 1975 - Searching for Black Holes in Space
  4. 1984 - DNA Fingerprinting discovered
  5. 1994 - Textbook of Hypertension published
  6. 2000 - One of the most important sociologists of the twentieth Century
  7. 2012 - The discovery of Richard III
  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Genetics Black holes Magazine:Staff Research WW1 Architecture Astronomy DNA Buildings Education Archaeology Leicester 2013-09-27T09:40:00Z Blog Entry Are we alone in the universe? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/public-lecture-to-explore-if-we-are-alone-in-the-universe Dr Lewis Dartnell to deliver public lecture on Astrobiology and the potential for alien life Dr Lewis Dartnell, a UK Space Agency research fellow based at the University, will deliver a lecture to the public on Thursday, 17 October offering a glimpse into the potential for alien life existing in outer space.

The session will discuss an array of engaging topics, from how life emerged on our planet to where in the cosmos we might expect to find alien life.

Alongside his Astrobiology research, Dr Dartnell writes regular science articles in newspapers and magazines and has appeared in TV shows such as BBC Stargazing live, Wonders of the Universe and Horizon.

Dr Dartnell\ufffd\ufffdhas also published a popular science book introducing Astrobiology entitled\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLife in the Universe: A Beginner\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Guide\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and has illustrated a children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds book.

The lecture will take place in Room E of the Physics and Astronomy Building Thursday, 17 October from 6.00 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 7.30pm.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Space Astronomy 2013-09-26T10:35:00Z Blog Entry University to host major supercomputing event https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/university-to-host-major-national-supercomputing-event Department of Physics and Astronomy researchers to present at DiRAC Day 2013 The University\ufffd\ufffdwill host DiRAC Day 2013, a major national supercomputing event, on Monday 23 September 10.30 - 5.00pm, in the Stamford Court Conference Centre.

The team from the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Physics and Astronomy will present the latest scientific advances which have been made possible by the Distributed Research utilising Advanced Computing (DiRAC) supercomputer.

Researchers\ufffd\ufffdfrom Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Theoretical Astrophysics Group within the Department of Physics and Astronomy are currently using the \ufffd\ufffd2 million "Complexity"computer -\ufffd\ufffdthe node of DiRAC hosted by the University - on a number of exciting projects.

During the event, Leicester researchers will also present findings from their other DiRAC research projects \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including planet formation within other solar systems and dark matter.

The DiRAC facility was launched in 2012, and has allowed researchers to model physical processes governing the evolution of the Universe in far greater detail than was previously possible.

  • BBC News feature on the Complexity computer
  • BBC News feature on 'black hole secret'
  • Press Release
]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Astronomy Magazine:Student Physics and Astronomy 2013-09-20T15:55:00Z Blog Entry Leicester expert\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research on brown dwarfs features in New Scientist https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/august/leicester-expert2019s-research-on-brown-dwarfs-features-in-new-scientist Dr Sarah Casewell explains extreme weather effects observed on brown dwarfs in close orbit around white dwarfs World-leading research by Dr Sarah Casewell of our Department of Physics and Astronomy has featured in the latest issue of New Scientist magazine.

Dr Casewell is carrying out research into brown dwarfs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfailed stars\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd which, unlike stars, are unable to sustain thermonuclear fusion of normal hydrogen in their cores.

Her work particularly focuses on brown dwarfs in close binaries with white dwarfs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd very dense remnants of low to medium mass stars which have reached the end of their life cycle.

Her expertise in this area made her an ideal person to provide commentary for the New Scientist's piece on brown dwarfs' unusual status as a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhalf star, half planet\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

She explains how brown dwarfs can be locked in orbit around white dwarfs, with only one side ever facing the white dwarf.

As a result, one side will be irradiated by the immensely hot white dwarf while the other side remains cool.

This can produce dramatic weather phenomena according to Dr Casewell \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including supersonic winds which transfer heat from one side of the planet to another.

What\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds more \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd her observations of brown dwarfs can act as a useful proxy for working out what conditions could be like on planets outside our solar system.

Exoplanets tend to be too faint and hard to detect \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd but thankfully, this is not the case with brown dwarfs, which tend to be 13 to 75 times the mass of Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system.

Dr Casewell uses European Southern Observatory's New Technology Telescope (NTT) and Very Large Telescope (VLT) and the NASA Spitzer Space Telescope to observe four separate brown dwarfs paired with white dwarfs.

\ufffd\ufffd

You can read the full feature in the latest issue of New Scientist (August 24) or on the magazine\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds website (paywall).

]]> No publisher mlrc3 Space Astronomy Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Research 2013-08-30T12:50:02Z Blog Entry University of Leicester leads scientists in bid to understand Universe - using X-rays https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/university-of-leicester-leads-scientists-in-bid-to-understand-universe-using-x-rays-1 Leicester-led research project maps record numbers of cosmic X-ray sources

Three years of research led by\ufffd\ufffdthe University of Leicester has produced a new catalogue of over 500,000 detections of x-ray emissions, and over 300,000 emitters\ufffd\ufffd\ufffda new record, and an unparalleled resource for scientists exploring the extremes of Universe as we know it. The XMM-Newton Survey Science Centre, led by a team from the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Physics and Astronomy, used the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdALICE\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd supercomputer to help them produce a new X-ray catalogue, called \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd3XMM\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

These findings help us map some of the wildest parts of space, and some of the rarest and most extreme phenomena seen in the Universe: for instance prodigious outbursts of X-rays lead us to the tidal disruptions caused by black holes swallowing stars. \ufffd\ufffdAdditionally, the information allows scientists to generate large, well-defined samples of objects, such as active galactic nuclei, which includes galaxies that swirl around supermassive black holes, galactic clusters, which are gargantuan webs containing billions of stars, and stellar coronae\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthe huge amounts of plasma blasted out into space by stars.

The XMM-Newton Survey Science Centre is one of the teams behind the European Space Agency's (ESA) X-ray Multi-Mirror Mission (XMM-Newton). Since Earth's atmosphere blocks out all X-rays, only a telescope in space can detect and study celestial X-ray sources. The XMM-Newton mission is helping scientists to solve a number of cosmic mysteries, ranging from the enigmatic black holes to the origins of the Universe itself.

  • View a map of the objects in the 3XMM catalogue
  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Space Magazine:Staff Space Projects Astronomy Magazine:Student 2013-07-24T09:20:00Z Blog Entry The beginning of time: world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds oldest calendar may have been discovered by archaeologists https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/the-beginning-of-time-world2019s-oldest-calendar-discovered-by-archaeologists University of Leicester archaeoastronomer advises archaeological team on their discovery of what could be the oldest calendarical monument in the world A team of archaeologists has discovered what they believe to be the oldest calendrical monument known anywhere in the world, created by hunter-gatherer societies in Scotland and dating back to around 8000 BC.

Researchers discovered that a monument created by hunter gatherers in Aberdeenshire nearly 10,000 years ago appears to mimic the phases of the Moon in order to track lunar months over the course of a year.

The site, at Warren Field, Crathes, also aligns on the Midwinter Sunrise, providing an annual astronomic correction in order to maintain the link between the passage of time, indicated by the Moon, the asynchronous solar year and the associated seasons.

Clive Ruggles, Emeritus Professor of Archaeoastronomy at the University of Leicester,\ufffd\ufffdadvised the team on archaeoastronomical issues. He points out that there is no evidence that the site marked particular moonrises.

You can read more about the discovery here

  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Student Astronomy Magazine:Staff Archaeology Archaeoastronomy 2013-07-17T11:17:54Z Blog Entry
